question_text: A 38-year-old woman develops a new generalized rash 1 day following administration of amoxicillin-clavulanate.A portion of the rash is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The patient most likely has acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (Option A), which is characterized by a rapid onset of a pustular rash following a medication exposure in a patient without a history of psoriasis. Patients present with fever and erythema, and then develop myriad dense non-folliculocentric pustules, primarily in skin folds and on the trunk. The onset of the rash may be as soon as 1 day after exposure to the medication and up to a few days at most. Eighty percent of cases are caused by antibiotics, most typically penicillins, sulfonamides, and quinolones. In contrast, generalized pustular psoriasis occurs in patients with psoriasis, usually following withdrawal of systemic glucocorticoid therapy (often prescribed for a separate indication).
